snippet: A tablet upon the modern house No. 8 Chambers Street, between South Bridge Street and West Col lege Street, states that it was built upon the site of the birthplace of Sir Walter Scott. This stood at the head of College Wynd, described as " a steep and straitened alley" ascending from the Cowgate towards the southern side of the town. It was orig inally called the Wynd of the Blessed-Mary-in-the- Field, and what is left of it is now called Guthrie Street, perhaps after the famous Dr. Guthrie, who never officially recognized the Blessed Mary any where.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: 52 LITERARY LANDMARKS OF EDINBURGH To follow the footsteps of Sir Walter Scott in Edinburgh, it is only necessary to walk through all the streets and alleys of the Old Town, and through most of the streets and avenues of the New. De spite his fondness for Abbotsford, he was a thorough cockney at heart, and he knew and loved every inch of the smoky old city from the College Wynd to St. Andrew Square. He limped at full speed up and down the Cowgate in his boyhood ; and " no funeral hearse," says Lockhart, " crept more leisurely than did his landau in his middle age up the Canongate; not a queer tottering gable but recalled to him some long-buried memory of splendor or bloodshed, which by a few words he set before the hearer in the real ity of life."

title: Out of her Shroud. [A novel.]
author: Ochiltree, Henry.
snippet: Already the sun had gone far below the zenith, and was altogether obscured by some of the higher buildings. Loth to leave the brightness which he had that day so much enjoyed, Frederick crossed to the other side of the street—the sunny side—and was making his way up the College Wynd —formerly called the Wynd of the Blessed Virgin Mary-of-the-Fields—when he was encountered by a lady of exceedingly dignified step and haughty manner. Sharp features of the oval type, keen black eyes surmounted with mobile arching eyebrows, lofty forehead, above which was perched a huge piece of architecture composed largely of ribbon and lace, and the long-flowing, lappeted mantle which gave her an air of dignity and authority marked the general outline of her appearance.

title: Out of her Shroud. [A novel.]

snippet: IT was a fresh, late April morning, radiant with the early sunshine, whose rays were reflected in brilliant flashes from the dewdrops which hung tenderly on the few green blades of a grass-plot immediately under the window. The College Wynd was but sparsely adorned with anything of the nature of herbage, although to the back of the Wynd, facing the south, a few solitary plots of grass and coarse flowers helped in a certain way to relieve the monotony of stone and lime. In a room overlooking one of these, Mona Sibbald awoke on this particular morning to the great realisation of wifehood.
